text.tspan: The Earth has gone through natural changes before, the
climate models are constantly changing, and predictions
seem to be all over the place. There has always been
change.
And what about the Climategate incident with all those
leaked emails from scientists manipulating data? Doesn't
that undermine the credibility of climate research? It
exposed a lot of dishonesty within the scientific
community. Those leaked emails showed scientists
manipulating data to fit their narrative. It's hard to
trust the scientific process when you see researchers
trying to suppress dissenting views. It seemed like they
were more interested in pushing an agenda than presenting
objective data. The fact that these scientists were
caught manipulating data in the first place suggests
otherwise. How can we trust the entire field when there's
evidence of bias?
We can't just ignore it. Those scientists were caught
red-handed, trying to control the narrative, which
undermines the whole foundation of climate science. It's
hard to take climate science seriously when there's
evidence of such blatant bias.
